questions.text: Study the image given below and identify the embryological basis of the condition shown:

options.label: B
options.text: Failure of closure of posterior neuropore

options.label: A

options.label: B

questions.text: A muscle has 140 mM of a bivalent cation present extracellularly while the intracellular concentration of the same cation is 14 mM. Assuming that 2.3 RT/F = 60 mV, what would be the membrane potential if the membrane were permeable to only this ion?

options.text: Starting body temperature = 37.2°C; high point in body temperature = 38.9°C; final body temperature after feedback correction = 37.4°C

options.label: C
options.text: Starting blood glucose = 80 mg/dL; high point in blood glucose = 110 mg/dL; final blood glucose after feedback correction = 85 mg/dL

options.label: D
options.text: Starting plasma osmolality = 280 mOsm/kg; low point in plasma osmolality = 270 mOsm/kg; final osmolality after feedback correction = 278 mOsm/kg

questions.correct_answer: B. Starting body temperature = 37.2°C; high point in body temperature = 38.9°C; final body temperature after feedback correction = 37.4°C

A 51-year-old male patient has suffered from fluctuating right sensorineural hearing loss with vertigo since 2 yrs. Last year he was first admitted to our hospital due to a severe vertigo attack accompanied by right sensorineural hearing loss. Spontaneous nystagmus toward the right side was observed. Since April 2004, he has experienced vertigo spells with right-sided tinnitus a few times per month that are intractable to conventional medical therapy. After four months, tympanic tube insertion was preformed in the right tympanic membrane. Intratympanic injection of dexamethasone was ineffective,Which of the following statement is most appropriate

options.label: A
options.text: Car hart’s notch is a characteristic feature in pure tone audiogram

options.label: B
options.text: Schwartz’s sign is usually present in the tympanic membrane

options.label: C
options.text: Low frequency sensorineural deafness is often seen in pure tone audiogram

options.label: D
options.text: Decompression of fallopian canal is the treatment of choice

questions.correct_answer: C. Low frequency sensorineural deafness is often seen in pure tone audiogram

options.text: Only one dT vaccine at 5th month

questions.correct_answer: A. Diphtheria-Tetanus vaccine stat and after one month

questions.text: A 32 years old G3P2 L2 with 38 weeks of gestation is in active labour. Her fetus is of average size and weight. She had two normal deliveries in past. She has multiple, painful, fluid-filled vesicles on her external genitalia. What should be the plan of treatment in this case?

options.label: A
options.text: Give acyclovir, conduct vaginal delivery and give acyclovir to the neonate

options.label: B
options.text: Give acyclovir, conduct emergency caesarean section

options.label: C
options.text: Conduct vaginal delivery and give acyclovir to the neonate

options.label: D
options.text: Conduct caesarean section and there is no need of acyclovir

questions.correct_answer: B. Give acyclovir, conduct emergency caesarean section

questions.text: In a case of eclampsia, if we are giving Pritchard’s regimen then which one of the following would be a reason to stop the maintenance dose?
Puerperal tubal ligation is allowed within how many days of delivery?
How much is the normal uterocervical length in a reproductive aged, non-pregnant female?
After how many days of fertilisation is the event of implantation in the uterus?
A 27 years old primigravida has 38 weeks of gestation with non-identical twins. The presentation is cephalo-breech. Which one of the following is the correct management in this case?
Which of the following complications is not seen in MCMA twins?
Identify the given position of the fetus:
Which of the following investigations is not done in QUADRUPLE marker test?
Identify the investigation shown in this picture?

A 20-month-old, previously healthy boy is being evaluated for poor weight gain for 4 to 5 months, and watery diarrhea, bloating, and poor appetite for 3 weeks. He currently passes stools 4 to 6 times daily, wakes up with stool in his diaper, and has a significant diaper rash. He has had no vomiting or hematochezia. The boy’s physical examination findings demonstrate a weight of 10 kg (7th percentile), length of 87 cm (54th percentile), and weight/length less than the 1st percentile. He appears tired and has thin extremities. His abdomen is soft, moderately distended, and nontender, without mass or organomegaly. Moderate diaper dermatitis is present. Stool testing shows the following results: Fecal ova and parasite examination- Negative Giardia antigen- Negative Fecal bacterial culture- Negative Fecal fat- 43% (reference range <20%) Pancreatic elastase >500 μg/g (reference range >200) Fecal occult blood Negative Fecal white blood cells Negative Of the following, the MOST likely cause of this boy’s diarrhoea is

A 30-week-gestation pregnant woman is seen at the obstetrician’s office for a febrile illness. Her symptoms include headache and joint pain. She has had routine prenatal care and no complications of pregnancy. Physical examination reveals the rash shown below. She asks how this illness may affect her newborn. Of the following, the MOST accurate response is that a likely sequela is

An expectant mother is seen for a prenatal visit. Prenatal genetic testing performed on her fetus showed karyotype 45,X. She will be meeting with a genetic counselor in the coming days. Of the following, the MOST likely cardiac disorder to be seen in this fetus is

A female neonate born at term is evaluated in the neonatal intensive care unit. The pregnancy was complicated by maternal gestational diabetes and alcohol exposure. Prenatal ultrasonography at 20 weeks showed intrauterine growth retardation. The neonate is presently intubated. Her birth weight is 2,200 g. She has a small jaw, clenched hands with overlapping fingers, rocker-bottom feet, a short sternum, and hypoplastic nails. Echocardiography shows a ventricular septal defect. Renal ultrasonography shows a horseshoe kidney. Of the following, the MOST likely diagnosis is

A pediatrician receives a phone call from the state’s newborn screening program regarding a 7-day-old neonate with an elevated trypsinogen, which is concerning for a diagnosis of cystic fibrosis. The neonate was seen by the pediatrician’s partner 1 day ago and had appropriate feeding and growth parameters as well as normal vital signs and physical examination findings. The partner noted that there is no significant family history of diseases in childhood. Of the following, the MOST appropriate next step is to

options.label: A
options.text: Inform the parents of the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis

options.label: B
options.text: Discuss the result at the 2-month health supervision visit

options.label: C
options.text: Reassure the parents that this is likely a false-positive result

options.label: D
options.text: Schedule the neonate for diagnostic testing

questions.correct_answer: D. Schedule the neonate for diagnostic testing

questions.text: A 10 year old child weighing 30kg presents with a history of loose stools for 2 days. On examination, there is severe dehydration. Laboratory investigations were as follows. What is the initial management as per ISPAD guidelines? RBS- 550 mg/dl pH- 7.01 Na+- 158mEq/L Urine glucose- 3+

options.label: A
options.text: Manage ABC, NS 20ml/kg and start insulin after 1 hour

options.label: B
options.text: Manage ABC, NS 20ml/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr

options.label: C
options.text: Manage ABC, NS 10ml/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr

options.label: D
options.text: Manage ABC, NS 10ml/kg and start insulin after 1 hour

questions.correct_answer: A. Manage ABC, NS 20ml/kg and start insulin after 1 hour

questions.text: Which of the following is the best sign to indicate adequate growth in an infant with a birth weight of 2.8kg?

options.label: A
options.text: Increase in length 25cm in the first year

options.label: B
options.text: Weight gain of 300g per month till 1 year

options.label: C
options.text: Anterior frontanelle closure by 6 months of age

options.label: D
options.text: Weight under 75th percentile and height under 25th percentile

questions.correct_answer: A. Increase in length 25cm in the first year

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant is brought to the pediatric clinic with a history of deafness, bilateral cataracts, and a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). The parents are concerned about the possibility of an underlying syndrome that might explain these findings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this infant?

A 3-month-old infant is evaluated for persistent jaundice and elevated liver enzymes. A liver biopsy is performed, revealing findings consistent with extensive bile duct proliferation. Given this presentation and biopsy result, which of the following diagnoses is most consistent with the biopsy findings?

A 2-month-old infant presents with hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, and periventricular calcifications seen on neuroimaging. The infant also shows developmental delays and sensorineural hearing loss. These findings are consistent with a congenital infection that commonly affects multiple organ systems and can cause significant developmental and neurological impairments. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Which grading system is used for arteriovenous malformation?
The radiograph shown below for better assessment of frontal sinuses. What is the common name of the view shown.
35 years old male, expansile swelling of distal forearm, near wrist joint. Xray Shown
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • 2. Other options: Ewing's Sarcoma: • Occurs in children or adolescents. • Typically involves the diaphysis of long bones. • X-ray shows an aggressive lesion with periosteal reaction (onion skin appearance).
  • • Osteoid Osteoma: • Small, benign tumor (less than 2 cm). • Common in the cortex of long bones. • X-ray shows a radiolucent nidus with surrounding sclerosis.
  • • Osteochondroma: • Benign tumor arising from the bone surface. • Appears as a bony outgrowth (exostosis) with a cartilage cap.

questions.text: Child playing left unattended by the mother. Develops diﬃculty swallowing. No distress. CXR shown. Where is the foreign body?
A false negative F-18 FDG PET study is MOST likely to occur in which one of the following lung carcinomas?
